textBeforeTable: Specifying ROW_FORMAT=COMPRESSED or KEY_BLOCK_SIZE in CREATE TABLE or ALTER TABLE statements produces the following warnings if the Barracuda file format is not enabled. You can view them with the SHOW WARNINGS statement. 14.9.6 SQL Compression Syntax Warnings and Errors 14.9.6 SQL Compression Syntax Warnings and Errors 14.9.5 How Compression Works for InnoDB Tables 14.9.4 Monitoring Compression at Runtime 14.9.3 Tuning Compression for InnoDB Tables 14.9.2 Enabling Compression for a Table 14.9.1 Overview of Table Compression 14.9 InnoDB Table Compression [Toggle] Section Navigation       14.10 InnoDB File-Format Management » « 14.9.5 How Compression Works for InnoDB Tables //--> } } document.getElementById(what).style.display = "none"; }else{ document.getElementById(what).style.display = "block"; if(document.getElementById(what).style.display == "none"){ function toggle(what){
textAfterTable: Notes: By default, these messages are only warnings, not errors, and the table is created without compression, as if the options were not specified. When innodb_strict_mode is enabled, MySQL generates an error, not a warning, for these cases. The table is not created if the current configuration does not permit using compressed tables. The “non-strict” behavior lets you import a mysqldump file into a database that does not support compressed tables, even if the source database contained compressed tables. In that case, MySQL creates the table in ROW_FORMAT=COMPACT instead of preventing the operation. To import the dump file into a new database, and have the tables re-created as they exist in the original database, ensure the server has the proper settings for the configuration parameters innodb_file_format and innodb_file_per_table. The attribute KEY_BLOCK_SIZE is permitted only when ROW_FORMAT is specified as COMPRESSED or is omitted. Specifying a KEY_BLOCK_SIZE with any other ROW_FORMAT generates a warning that you can view with SHOW WARNINGS. However, the table is non-compressed; the specified KEY_BLOCK_SIZE is ignored).
